R: @robertwb please merge.
Rebased to see if it helps to fix the `WordCountIT` failure (investigating in the mean time).

I propose this, keep the change in the [README](url). And convert the exceptions in the [setup.py](url) to soft warnings (log messages) that says something along the lines of "You are using version ... of pip/cython however at least ... version of that is recommended.".

This also makes sense for our users. For `cython` SDK works with older versions, for `pip` SDK works with older version except for one case where we use the `--no-binary` flag. There might be some users with older version of a `pip` and who never use this feature, we do not want to break them. And they will also be aware that if they experience a problem in the future they should first try upgrading their `pip`.
Addition tests? There's a number of public classes which don't have unit tests. It'd also be nice to see a `RunnableOnService` test which demonstrates usage in a pipeline.
Oops, forgot to push updates. Done now.
Thanks! LGTM.
Getting close! Looks like just one or two nontrivial root causes for the remaining `RunnableOnService` tests. I'll also read over the code again once they are all passing.
Is that similar to what you had in mind?
OK, I rebased, added unit tests, and addressed most comments. I'll address the couple more final comments meanwhile, but as far as I'm concerned this PR should be good to go modulo cosmetics.
OK, I decided to change this PR to simply reduce the number of these warnings, but not upgrade them to errors, in order to reduce future work when we find a way to cleanly make this an error.

R: @lukecwik 
CC: @dhalperi

@dhalperi 

Haven't seen any response on this in a few days.  Let me know if I should ping someone else on this.  If there's anything else you'd like to see changed, please lat me know!  Thank you sir.
@dhalperi thanks for review. Added comments + some fixes.
R: @kennknowles or any other committer who knows the SDK well.
I absolutely do not understand the dependency issue you're seeing - given that you haven't modified any of the maven stuff especially

@dhalperi 

Sorry, didn't mean to imply you weren't responding fast enough.  Hadn't figured out the cadence of this project and I wasn't sure if I was even pinging the correct maintainer ;)

WRT your main question, which was completely expected, when I wrote the original version that subclassed FileBasedSink, I ran into issues with the GZIPOutputStream not writing the required end of file data unless I called `GZIPOutputStream.finish()`.  Ie, even after FileBasedWriter called `close()` on the Gzip stream, the end Gzip data would not be written to the file, leaving it corrupt.

I'll double check that today, while I make the other changes.  Thanks again!
Still a prototype, and WIP
LGTM

This change may ~double the memory consumption due to singleton side inputs with defaults that are accessed. Since that is proportional to the number of empty windows accessed, I wouldn't expect it to be relevant. And anyhow, it is actually incorrect prior to your change. If it becomes a problem, we'll have to think of other ways to address it.
I agree. Thanks for merging!
@chamikaramj This is ready for review : )
Thanks Robert.

Just tried with myself, I haven't talk to spark or flink people yet. TestFlinkRunner doesn't terminate streaming job automatically, and TestSparkRunner has an operation registration error which needs more investigation.

(we don't actually need `StateTag`, I don't think, but on the other hand in the absence of language-supported tuples, it is handy)

LOL, yep, don't need to `finish()` method!!!

Added the checkstyle test, and confirmed it forbids what it ought to.

Great! Keep at it, at least figuring out why Spark is broken. If you haven't, you should file JIRA issues and also loop in @amitsela and (@aljoscha or @mxm)

OTOH, the layer that might really benefit most from this is `DoFnRunner`, in which case `DoFnInvoker` might not require it.

From a quick look at it it seems that the input to the pipeline is `TextIO`. Shouldn't it use `UnboundedReadFromBoundedSource` ?
The Spark runner should have `Read.Unbounded` support soon enough, but I thought that an `UnboundedSource` is actually necessary for a streaming pipeline.. 
I even plan on making the `isStreaming` options implicit.
What am mI missing here ?
Yeah, the updated PR description helps. Thanks!
R: @chamikaramj, can you please take a look?

There are a few enhancements needed and parts missing from the current PR, in order for BZIP2 support to be complete.

These are all actually taken care of in https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1053
Does it make sense to proceed with that PR instead of the current one?

R: @jkff 
CC: @dkulp
By the way, I will check if there's no execution conflict with the javadoc goal performed in the release profile and the default one present in the main `pom.xml`.
What do you think about this gist: https://gist.github.com/jbonofre/b87f7b8eee03da1b228bc4b1af91fd87 ?

I'll do a more thorough review later, but two quick comments:
1) With the builder pattern, it's possible that the required Parser is null.   This should be checked in the validate method.

2) I'm not exactly "happy" about making the common Read<String> case more complex.  I understand the AutoValue/builder pattern might be limiting some flexibility there.  I'll try and play around with a few things later.   One thought is to have two Read methods:

```
    Read<String> read()
    Read<T> read(Parser<T> p)
```

since the parser is required for the non-string case.

Good point.

Using two read methods with different signature can work for sure.

OK, made the requested changes.  Thanks again.  Still have a few diffs in there due to formatting, but it looks like there was previous inconsistent rules around whitespace before and after braces in array inits.
Is there any other place we are moving these examples to? I can imagine users taking this code and modifying it to their needs.
Closing this for now till I do more testing on whether these signals are needed.

LGTM. Agree with the good question and the reply. Every `KeyedWorkItem` (elements or timers) is globally windowed, not required to contain only one window's data/timers, and the window information is contained within its components. I'll wait for tests then merge.

I'm currently on vacation but I can have a look next week when I get back.

**Note:**
This PR originally came to address "enabling" ROS tests after they were disabled.
It turned into re-implementing the runner to support the Beam model in full.

_Most_ of the work was on combine (key/globally) implementation to include `CombineWithContext`  support, but not only.

Another important note is testing: except for `testSessionsCombineWithContext` which is being discussed as [BEAM-696](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-696) all ROS tests pass (batch).
With that in mind I would like to remove Spark's own custom tests that are covered by ROS. One thing comes to mind is the fact that `PAssert` now tests from within a DoFn and Spark's lazy nature will simply not run the DoFn if for some reason it won't ingest any input data (or drop something before the assert phase) and thus won't fail.

This PR is a bit "bulky", but I hope that'll put the runner back on track, so excuse me for that.

R: @kennknowles, @dhalperi 
Also @jbonofre PTAL

Merged as is, with the JIRA issues Mark has (or will) file for the other runners.

Amit, I think maybe the Spark runner needs to add support for `UnboundedReadFromBoundedSource`. Spark runner may not be using it yet -- but it's in `runners-core` module.
Btw can you post a diff of the javadoc output?

Now that I've had a chance to think about this a little, I don't think the context class loader is necessarily the best answer. The important thing is for the user's `DoFn` class to be available from the generated class. It is also required that the generated class is available from the worker code, obviously. Can we use `fnClass.getClassLoader()`?
